question: For how long is an aircraft’s certificate of registration valid?

choices.choice: Till the aircraft is destroyed in an accident
Till it is cancelled by DGCA

subject: Regulations
explanation:
The registration remains valid as long as the aircraft is operational and in compliance with the applicable regulations unless the DGCA decides to cancel it for any reason.

\n

subject: Regulations
explanation: \n

question: Which letter combinations are not allowed in registration marks due to possible confusion with signals?

choices.choice: Three letters combinations used in the international code of signals
Four letter combinations beginning with Q
Five letter combinations used in the international code of signals

subject: Regulations
explanation:
Certain combinations of letters are not permitted to be used as registration
letters or parts of a registration mark. These are those combinations of letters used for specific
distress traffic indicators or internationally accepted communication abbreviations. Specifically:
• SOS (Distress – morse)
• PAN (Urgency)
• XXX (Urgency – morse)
• TTT (Safety /Securité – morse)
• ‘Q’ codes (i.e. QNH; QRT; QUG etc….)
• 5 letter combinations of the international Code of Signals.

question: Registration marks must consist of letters, numbers, or a mix, and are assigned by whom?

choices.choice: The state of registry or common mark registering authority

subject: Regulations
explanation:
The registration mark shall be letters, numbers, or a combination of letters and numbers consisting of 1 to 5 digits or characters and shall be that assigned by the state of registry or common mark registering authority.

\n

question: From where is the common mark for aircraft registration selected?

choices.choice: To the International Civil Aviation Organisation by the International Telecommunication Union
To the state of registry by the International Civil Aviation Organisation

subject: Regulations
explanation:
Each international operating agency must be assigned a distinctive common mark by ICAO, selected by ICAO from a series of symbols included in the radio call signs allocated to ICAO by the International Telecommunication Union (ITU).

\n

question: What should be the minimum height of aircraft markings on the fuselage and vertical tail of heavier-than-air aircraft?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
The height of the marks on the wings of heavier-than-air aircraft must be at least 50 centimeters: 

Part of aircraft

Height of marks

Wings

At least 50 centimeters

Fuselage or vertical tail surfaces

At least 30 centimeters

question: Which combinations of letters in registration are prohibited because they may be confused with urgent signals?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
PAN is used as a distress call indicating urgency, while RCC stands for “Rescue Coordination Center,” which is not a distress signal. LLL does not have a recognized urgency associated with it.

\n

question: The minimum size for under-wing registration marks on heavier-than-air aircraft is what?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
The height of the marks on the wings of heavier-than-air aircraft must be at least 50 centimeters: 

Part of aircraft

Height of marks

Wings

At least 50 centimeters

Fuselage or vertical tail surfaces

At least 30 centimeters

question: Which nationality mark has been assigned to India by ITU?

choices.choice: Letters VT and VW, both included

subject: Regulations
explanation:
India has allotted nationality symbols AT to AW by the ITU. However, we continue to use pre-independence nationality marks. The nationality mark used for aircraft registered in India is the letter “VT” for civil aircraft and “VU” for Air-force aircraft. The nationality mark for unmanned aircraft registered in India is “U”.

\n
